Table 3 Entry Substrate Catalyst (5mol%) Time (min) Conversion (%) 1 Image, table 3 oCB/TPP 130 >99 2 oCB/2HT 480 98 3 Image, table 3 oCB/TPP 20 99 4 oCB/2HT 480 98 5 Image, table 3 oCB/TPP 240 99 6 oCB/2HT 480 98 7 Image, table 3 oCB/TPP 1260 40 8 oCB/2HT 480 95 Heterogeneous phosphonium–carbon based PTC catalyst: From mechanochemical synthesis to SN2 type reaction in water Aida Kiani Methodology Software Validation Visualization Investigation Data curation Formal analysis Daniele Coscia Methodology Software Formal analysis Rosaria Schettini Conceptualization Visualization Supervision Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing 1 Maria Rosaria Acocella Conceptualization Visualization Supervision Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing ⁎ 1 Department of Chemistry and Biology A. Zambelli, University of Salerno Via Giovanni Paolo II, 84084 Fisciano (Sa) Italy Department of Chemistry and Biology A. Zambelli University of Salerno Via Giovanni Paolo II Fisciano Sa 84084 Italy Department of Chemistry and Biology A. Zambelli, University of Salerno Via Giovanni Paolo II, 84084 Fisciano (Sa) Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this paper. The use of phosphonium-carbon-based PTC as a catalyst in water solution is here described and its performances are discussed. The synthesis is realized via a mechanochemical process in solvent-free conditions respecting most of the green metrics for a sustainable procedure. The heterogeneous phase-transfer catalyst is fully characterized and used for SN2-type reaction of NaSCN with variously substituted benzyl bromides. The reaction proceeds with high efficiency in the presence of 5mol% of catalyst in water up to >99% of conversion. The catalyst can be easily recycled without losing productivity providing a green procedure. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Sustainability Phase-transfer catalysis Phosphonium salt Carbon black Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction PTC (phase-transfer catalysis) has been widely recognized in both industry and academia as an effective method for organic synthesis, involving mild reaction conditions, efficient experimental procedures, and environmentally benign organocatalysts that tolerate air and moisture [1]. Thus, PTC [2] plays a key role in sustainable chemistry in terms of significantly reduced waste, low toxicity, and low cost, meeting most of the green metrics required by Green Chemistry [3]. Based on the ability of the PTC catalysts to facilitate the migration of a reactant from one phase into another one, it is used to carry reactants across two immiscible phases, enabling reactions that are generally not possible via conventional synthesis routes. Although recently several molecules were shown to be used as efficient PTC catalysts, such as crown ethers [4], cryptands [5], calixarenes [6,7], cyclodextrins [8], and cyclic peptoids [9], the most commonly used for organic reactions and extensively investigated are onium salts such as quaternary ammonium [10–12] and phosphonium salts [13,14]. As onium salts are soluble in water, usually chosen as the second phase to reduce the need for organic solvents, possible recovery, and recycling is limited. It is therefore necessary to separate a PTC catalyst from the reaction mixture for isolation and purification when using it in soluble form. A more environmentally friendly approach might be to immobilize the onium salts on a solid support, which makes the separation of product and catalyst easier, and achieves an important green chemistry objective. In this direction, the phase-transfer catalysis is configured as an election methodology especially useful in green chemistry when the use of water avoids the organic solvents demand [15]. Many examples have been reported using, clays [14,16–18], polymers [19], polymer-clay composite [20], or porous inorganic polymers [21] that are able to efficiently catalyze some important organic reactions making easy catalyst recycling, but the diffusion properties to ensure the reagents reach the catalytic sites or the presence of the reactive sites just located on the surface, represent significant disadvantages of their use as supports in solid phase. Recently, carbon materials were used as mass-transfer promoters between two immiscible phases for the 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) production from hydrolysis of cellulose, being able to adsorbing non-hydrophilic molecules in aqueous solution and desorbing them in organic solution. Accelerating the selective extraction of the product in the organic phase through a sorption-desorption mechanism, it is possible to obtain higher conversion and selectivity [22]. In contrast with the physical sorption, a different and innovative approach was lately reported by using an ionic functionalization in an alkaline solution of carbon materials, such as oxidized carbon black, with ammonium quaternary salts. Specifically, a highly ordered intercalation compound of oxidized carbon black (oCB) in the presence of di-(hydrogenated tallow)-dimethylammonium chloride (2HT), was found to be an effective heterogeneous PTC catalyst for SN2-type reaction [23]. An ordered intercalate crystalline structure was obtained from highly disordered oCB in the presence of ammonium salts with long alkyl chains. The ionically bonded ammonium ions with long alkyl chains form a hexagonal rotator phase due to the perpendicular tails to the graphitic surface. The enriched graphene layers reassemble into an ordered intercalate structure [24]. This carbon intercalation compound was found to be an efficient PTC catalyst in an SN2 reaction conducted in a biphasic (liquid-liquid) environment and, more interestingly, for the first time in a water solution, providing the desired product in 95% conversion after 8 h. This heterogeneity guarantees the real possibility of an easy recycling of catalyst with negligible efficiency reduction, suggesting that cation exchange can be reversible. If the ionic functionalization of oCB can be easily performed by using an alkaline aqueous solution in the presence of the salt, just changing the counter ion it is possible to obtain other adducts with different possible catalytic activities. It was recently reported that oCB can form an ionic adduct with tetraphenyl phosphonium bromide (TPPBr), yielding a new filler, oCB/TPP [25]. More interestingly, it has been shown that dry ball milling can produce ionic functionalization without using a base in a significantly shorter time with higher stability and mass production than the solution-based process. This procedure allows a significant improvement over the synthesis carried out in the solution, and it is highly sustainable in terms of waste prevention. Therefore, being quaternary ammonium and phosphonium salts the most commonly used PTC catalysts, we decided to investigate the ability of the mechanochemical adduct oCB/TPP as a new heterogeneous PTC catalyst for SN2-type reaction. As a matter of fact, it is well known that the notable stability of phosphonium in comparison to ammonium ones as phosphonium-based PTC [26] offers the possibility to use them as ionic liquids (ILs), phase-transfer catalysts, and also as a tool for peptide coupling. Starting from a pioneer work described by Starks [1] using hexadecyltributylphosphonium bromide as a phase-transfer catalyst for the cyanation of alkyl bromide in a biphasic system, phosphonium ions have received increased interest. Additionally, phosphonium salts are well-known as organocatalysts for several fundamental reactions in organic synthesis and are useful phase-transfer catalysts also in the asymmetric version [13]. Our study presents the synthesis, characterization, and catalytic performance of oCB/TPP as a new heterogeneous PTC catalyst in a water solution nucleophilic substitution reaction. The procedure is completely green, from the catalyst synthesis conducted by dry grinding to the SN2 reaction conducted in a water solution, assuring conversion of up to 99% in a relatively short time. As a heterogeneous catalyst, it can be recycled up to five times without losing any efficiency. 2 Experimental Detailed descriptions for the synthesis of adducts of oCB with TPP (tetraphenyl phosphonium bromide), characterization, and general procedure for the nucleophilic substitution using oCB/TPP as PTC are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.1 Synthesis of the adduct oCB/TPP In order to prepare the oCB/TPP, an oCB sample obtained by Hummer's oxidation [27], with a 0.44 O/C ratio was used. A planetary ball mill Pulverisette 7 Premium (Fritsch GmbH, Germany) was used for ball-milling experiments at room temperature. A sample labeled oCB/TPP was obtained by mixing 50 mg of oCB powders and 50 mg TPPBr in an 80 ml silicon nitride jar. All procedures were performed with silicon nitride balls with a diameter of 10 mm rotating at 300 rpm for 30 min. Every five minutes, a five-minute break was taken during the milling process. Ball-milled samples were collected and weighed after milling to determine the mass yield. 2.2 General procedure for nucleophilic substitution using oCB/TPP as PTC in water All reactions were performed in water at room temperature using 4-methylbenzyl bromide (18.6 mg, 0.10 mmol) in H2O (0.25 M, 0.200 mL), and catalyst (5 mol%), with 0.75 M aqueous solution of thiocyanate salt (0.15 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred until total conversion unless otherwise stated. Reactions were monitored by TLC using precoated silica gel plates (0.25 mm) and visualized by UV light. The workup was performed by adding EtOAc, and after the solvent removal, the conversion percentage was determined by 1H NMR. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Mechanochemical synthesis of oCB/TPP adduct Carbon Black with a BET surface area of 130 m2/g was oxidized by the Hummers process [27] to yield oCB with an O/C ratio of 0.44. The mechanochemical functionalization was carried out according to the procedure previously reported [25]. After 30 min, the powder was collected without any solvent assistance and washed three times with water to eliminate the excess salt to provide the adduct with an 80% mass yield. The oCB/TPP adduct was characterized by elemental analysis, FTIR, WAXD, and TGA. (Fig. 1 ) As shown in Fig. 1A, the vibrations at 529, 694, 725, 764, 995, 1438, and 1480 cm−1 of TPP are evident in oCB/TPP. Based on the analysis of the spectral data, the band at 529 cm−1 is associated with the bending vibration of aromatic groups. Additionally, the 694, 725, 764, and 995 cm−1 bands are related to P-C stretching and phenyl-P vibrations, respectively. The 1438, 1480, and 1105 cm−1 bands correspond to C=C stretching aromatic vibrations and CH planar bending vibrations, respectively, which match the typical vibrations of phosphonium salts [28]. Furthermore, the X-ray diffraction pattern (Fig. 1B) shows that TPP crystallinity has been lost completely. This occurs due to the formation of the adduct and the absence of residual TPPBr. As within oCB/2HT [21,23], it might be expected that carbon black can afford intercalation compounds, but its amorphous nature, coupled with a counter-ion incapable of generating a hexagonal rotator phase, prevents X-ray diffraction patterns from predicting any structural order. The TGA analysis further confirmed the functionalization with the 15wt% TPP content by comparing it with oCB and TPPBr profiles (Fig. 1C). Elemental analysis also verified the TPP uptake, based on the rising carbon content with respect to starting oCB (see Supporting Information). Cation release at different pH levels, evaluated by UV measurement in the spectra range 250–350 nm on the aqueous solution, further confirmed the ionic nature of oCB/TPP. TPP kinetics release was investigated using neutral (pH = 7 with 10 wt% NaCl) and acid (pH = 1.3, HCl 0.05 M) solutions. Fig. 2 shows that in aqueous acidic solutions after 3 h, TPP ions are completely released, but in neutral water solutions even after 5 h, the release is negligible due to limited cation exchange. 3.2 Catalytic capability of oCB/TPP as PTC catalyst in water solution Based on our previous report [23], the oCB/TPP obtained by mechanochemical synthesis was tested as a possible PTC catalyst for the nucleophilic substitution of NaSCN in a water solution choosing 4-methyl benzyl bromide as a representative substrate (Scheme 1 ). Considering the functionalization degree, estimated by TGA analysis, a catalyst loading of 5mol% has been calculated and used in all reactions. Reaction monitoring by TLC and 1H NMR analysis allowed us to determine the conversion percentage. As reported in Table 1 , the reaction performed with 5mol% of oCB/TPP proceeds efficiently in 130 min providing a quantitative conversion of >99%. To figure out the effective catalytic ability of the adduct and if the functionalization could really affect its efficiency, both TPPBr salt and oCB were evaluated separately under the same reaction conditions (Table 1, entries 2 and 4). In the presence of oCB, the reaction gives just traces of the product after 130 min (Table 1, entry 4), while the phosphonium ion TPP afforded the product 87% and 99% of conversion after 130 min and 150 min, respectively (Table 1, entries 2 and 3). In a more detailed analysis of the reaction kinetics, the presence of oCB/TPP speeds up the reaction, particularly in the first few minutes. The reaction proceeds faster in the presence of oCB/TPP after 5 min than in the presence of TPPBr alone, providing 11% and 5% of conversion, respectively (Table 1, entry 7 vs 8). The conversion rate is still higher after 30 min of reaction giving 42% of conversion vs. 27% in the presence of TPPBr. Although Fig. 3 clearly shows the better catalytic performance of the oCB/TPP from the first minutes of the reaction until the end, the reaction rate in the presence of just TPPBr is not so far from the best catalytic performance of carbon black adduct (Table 1 entry 3 vs 1). On the other hand, the solubility of TPPBr in water represents a huge limitation to its application, being necessary to separate it from the reaction mixture by introducing an additional purification step and producing a higher amount of waste. Therefore, the heterogenization of the TPPBr through a facile functionalization of carbon black appears as a fundamental step to ensure the sustainability of the process. In order to optimize the procedure and define the best reaction condition additional experiments were performed to evaluate the possibility to reduce the catalyst loading. Interestingly, the reaction still works efficiently reducing the catalyst to 1mol% as well as to 0.1mol%, but prolonged reaction times, up to three times with respect to 5mol%, are required to reach the maximum conversion (Table 1, entries 9 and 10) confirming the 5mol% to be the best choice. For the sake of comparison, the same reaction was performed in the presence of the analogous adduct as freshly prepared by cation exchange in alkaline conditions [25], providing the same efficiency. In addition, the same reaction was performed in different acidic solutions and yielding a faster release of TPP, showed an acceleration of the reaction kinetics further demonstrating the oCB/TPP ionic nature (see supporting information). Table 2 summarizes the outcomes of the reaction between different alkylating agents and NaSCN, which were conducted under optimal conditions in water, to get a better understanding of the procedure's scope. As can be seen from Table 2, oCB/TPP is able to catalyze the reaction with high efficiency, achieving 99% conversion in most cases at different times depending on the substituent present on the aromatic ring. In particular, the reaction proceeds in only 20 min with benzyl bromide, while the presence of substituents in the para or ortho position (Table 2, entries 3,4,5,6) although electron withdrawing, prolongs the reaction time possibly due to the steric hindrance or potential interaction with the catalyst. Specifically, the electronic effects could be analyzed between substituents in the para position: the presence of a trifluoromethyl group enhances the reaction rate in comparison with a chloro substituent in the same position (Table 2, entry 6 vs 3). Conversely, in the presence of the nitro group, albeit strongly electron-withdrawing, the reaction requires 24 h to reach a 40% conversion (Table 2, entry 4) possibly indicating an interaction between the substituent and the active species that reduces the catalyst efficiency. At the same time, we hypothesize a potential steric effect when an ortho position is occupied for instance by a cyano group (Table 2, entry 5) reducing reaction rate if it is compared with all the other reactions reported. Probably, the presence of an ortho substitution influences the favorable interactions between the catalyst and substrate which occurs in the other cases. In the presence of aromatic substrates containing halogenated substituents, high conversions can be achieved, although the time required to complete the reaction depends on the extent of the substitution (Table 2, entries 3, 6, and 7). Conversely, with bromoalkane as the substrate (Table 2, entry 8), the reaction did not work even after 24 h. As a final step, we investigated the feasibility of recycling our heterogeneous catalyst by choosing the addition of NaSCN to 4-methylbenzyl bromide (1 mmol scale) as a reference reaction. All reactions were checked after 130 min and at the end of each cycle, the catalyst was recovered in the aqueous phase during the work-up and dried at 60 °C for 24 h. The resulting powder without further purification was reused in the next reaction to test its conversion efficiency. As reported in Fig. 4 , five recycling tests were conducted on the same catalyst yielding surprising results. Catalyst conversion remains consistently at 99%, indicating its exceptional stability and its ability to be easily recovered and reused without losing efficiency. 3.3 oCB/TPP vs oCB/2HT: a necessary comparison As previously reported, the adduct coming from the ionic functionalization of oCB with ammonium salt is able to efficiently catalyze the SN2-type reaction with benzyl bromide substrates in a water solution. Based on the hypothesized mechanism reported in our precedent paper [23], the reaction can occur thanks to a cation exchange between the oCB/2HT and NaSCN affording the 2HT/SCN ionic pair. The new ionic pair will move to the interface with the organic substrate for the SN2 nucleophilic substitution reaction to take place. The resulting 2HT/Br, after reacting with the sodium intercalation compound, yields the oCB/2HT once again. This hypothesis can also explain the catalyst recyclability. Here we have reported that the same catalytic activity is exerted by oCB/TPP, provided from the mechanochemical synthesis, and more interesting, the recycling test shows the possibility to reuse and recycle the catalyst without losing efficiency even after 5 cycles. According to this, the action mechanism may be similar to the one reported for oCB/2HT. It has to be noted that, although the efficiency is high with both catalysts, the reaction rate is significantly different, being oCB/TPP able to provide the products in a shorter reaction time. This is evident from a comparison of the activities for the same substrates, as shown in Table 3 (entries 1,3,5 vs. 2,4,6). The different reaction rate could be due to the relative highly ordered intercalated structure of oCB/2HT as observed from the presence of 001, 003, and 005 reflections and an additional reflection 100r at d = 0.42 nm associated with the perpendicular disposition of the alkyl tails to the graphitic planes (Fig. 5 Aa). This highly ordered structure could prevent a fast release of 2HT into the aqueous system and thus considerably slow down reaction speed. Additionally, 2HT is non-soluble in water reducing its total concentration in aqueous solution. Conversely, the X-ray diffraction pattern of oCB/TPP shows a broad amorphous halo not so different from the corresponding carbon black (Fig. 5Ab). Despite the amorphous nature of oCB due to the absence of a long-range order, it is characterized by the presence of small packs of graphitic layers in a spatially disordered arrangement [24]. As with graphite oxide, it might be assumed that oCB/TPP intercalation compounds can be formed. Considering the higher solubility of TPP than 2HT in water and the lack of the additional rotator order, due to the absence of alkyl chains in the TPP counter ion, it is reasonable to assume a faster cation exchange in NaSCN water solution, enabling TPP/SCN to be readily available for SN2 substitution. Fig. 5 reports a comparison between the WAXD of oCB/TPP and oCB/2HT and a possible pathway of their different tendency to release the cation in water solution. 4 Conclusion This contribution represents an important milestone in PTC describing first the synthesis of phosphonium carbon-based catalyst via mechanochemical approach and then its application for SN2 type reaction in water solution. Specifically, the oCB/TPP catalyst was obtained through an ionic functionalization by using a dry ball milling without using a base in a significantly shorter time with higher stability and mass production than the solution-based process. The oCB/TPP at 5mol% showed to efficiently catalyze the reaction of NaSCN with bromobenzyl derivatives in water, furnishing high conversion in a very short time and resulting in an effective PTC catalyst. In addition, a further reduction of the catalyst to 0.1 mol% can still result in high efficiency, albeit at the expense of increased reaction time. Being heterogeneous, oCB/TPP can be easily recovered in an aqueous solution and recycled without any loss in efficiency even after five runs. The catalytic efficiency combined with the mechanochemical ease of preparation makes the procedure highly sustainable and really interesting also for large-scale applications. Based on the results and our previous research, it is becoming increasingly clear that onium-carbon-based PTCs are highly effective catalysts in a water environment. This reinforces our belief that these catalysts have great potential for various applications and drives our research towards further studies on different organic reactions and also in the field of asymmetric phase-transfer catalysis. coredata.dc:description: The use of phosphonium-carbon-based PTC as a catalyst in water solution is here described and its performances are discussed. The synthesis is realized via a mechanochemical process in solvent-free conditions respecting most of the green metrics for a sustainable procedure. The heterogeneous phase-transfer catalyst is fully characterized and used for SN2-type reaction of NaSCN with variously substituted benzyl bromides. The reaction proceeds with high efficiency in the presence of 5mol% of catalyst in water up to >99% of conversion. The catalyst can be easily recycled without losing productivity providing a green procedure.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous phosphonium–carbon based PTC catalyst: From mechanochemical synthesis to SN2 type reaction in water
